Award.AwardTitle: URM: Mentoring Program in Neural Circuits and Behavior at the University of Puerto Rico
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to the University of Puerto Rico Medical Sciences Campus to establish an NSF Undergraduate Research and Mentoring (URM) program at the institution, in order to provide opportunities for undergraduate students to obtain research and mentoring experience in the field of neurobiology. Each year, for the first four years of the project, four students will be recruited to participate in the program, and the students will be provided NSF support for a period of two years. Over the five-year period of the grant, a total of sixteen students will participate in the program. Students from groups that are under-represented in neurobiology will be recruited following their second year of undergraduate study. Existing local networking mechanisms will be utilized to identify students from universities throughout Puerto Rico. Students will be engaged in ongoing faculty research programs on a year-round basis, with the objective of getting students to present and/or publish their work. The areas of research cover a broad range of topics, but are unified by the interdisciplinary goal of using the methods of neurobiology to increase our understanding of nervous system structure and function. Each program investigator has considerable mentoring experience, and the structure of faculty research programs enable undergraduate students to become rapidly involved in publication-quality research. The program mentoring strategy consists of personalized "hands-on" technical guidance that exposes students to state-of-the-art physiological, molecular and imaging approaches and equipment. Students are mentored in the scientific method, learning how to formulate hypotheses that are testable and appropriate to the questions they wish to answer. They are involved in all aspects of the research effort, including design of experiments, data collection, analysis, and communication of results. The importance of trust, cooperation, and teamwork within the "laboratory culture" is emphasized throughout the students' training. This individual mentoring experience is integrated within a highly interactive group setting that conveys and instills the excitement and enthusiasm of scientific exploration. Additional information is available at http://www.neuro.upr.edu/nsf-urm.html, or by contacting Dr. Mark Miller, at mark.miller@upr.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal goal of the Neural Circuits & Behavior program was to provide opportunities for undergraduate students to obtain research mentoring in the field of neurobiology. Students from groups that are under-represented in this discipline were enrolled following their second year of undergraduate study.  Existing local networking mechanisms were utilized to recruit applicants from universities throughout Puerto Rico.  Students were integrated into research programs on a year-round basis, with the objective of promoting their participation in studies that could reach the stage of national presentation and publication. Participant research projects covered a broad range of topics, but were unified by the interdisciplinary goal of neurobiology to increase our understanding of nervous system structure and function. The program mentoring strategy consisted of personalized “hands-on” technical guidance that exposed students to state-of-the-art physiological, molecular and imaging approaches and equipment.  Each of the program investigators had considerable mentoring experience and their research programs enabled undergraduate students to become rapidly involved in publication-quality research.  Students were mentored in the scientific method, learning how to formulate hypotheses that were testable and appropriate to the questions they were asking.  Participants were involved in all aspects of the experimental process, including design of experiments, data collection, analysis, and communication of results.  This individual mentoring experience was integrated within a highly interactive group setting that conveyed and instilled the excitement and enthusiasm of scientific exploration. 

The broader impacts of the Neural Circuits & Behavior URM addressed the national agenda to widen participation in the scientific workforce.  Students traveled to national conferences to present their work and to network with representatives from leading graduate schools.  The program also supported preparatory training for the Graduate Record Exam (GRE).  Outreach activities included ‘Family Night’ programs, visits to local schools, and participation in annual Brain Awareness Week (BAW) public presentations.  Of 21 student participants in this URM program, 9 (43%) entered graduate programs in a related discipline and 2 (10%) were admitted to MD-PhD programs with a concentration in neuroscience.   Graduates matriculated at highly prestigious institutions such as the University of Barcelona, Brown University, the University of Tübingen, and the University of California San Francisco.  This URM program identified and mentored outstanding undergraduate students who will become leading figures among the next generation of neuroscientists.
